questions.question: Is the numeric identifier in this market basket dataset approximately normally distributed? Return as JSON with keys: column, ks_statistic, p_value, is_normal, sample_mean, sample_std.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the smallest skewness, compute its mean and standard deviation, standardize the data, and apply a Kolmogorov‑Smirnov test against a standard normal distribution.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "column" (tested column), "ks_statistic" (rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), "is_normal" (boolean, true if p >= 0.05), "sample_mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "sample_std" (rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "height", "ks_statistic": 0.0456, "p_value": 0.234567, "is_normal": true, "sample_mean": 170.1234, "sample_std": 10.5678}

questions.question: Is there a significant difference in member numbers between two groups formed by a median split of another numeric variable? Return as JSON with keys: target_column, grouping_column, group1, group2, median1, median2, u_statistic, p_value.
questions.hint: Find the most skewed numeric column, create a binary grouping from another numeric column using its median, then compare group medians with a Mann‑Whitney U test.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 8 keys: "target_column", "grouping_column", "group1", "group2", "median1" (rounded to 4 decimals), "median2" (rounded to 4 decimals), "u_statistic" (rounded to 2 decimals), and "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals). Example: {"target_column": "score", "grouping_column": "treatment", "group1": "control", "group2": "experimental", "median1": 72.5000, "median2": 78.0000, "u_statistic": 1234.50, "p_value": 0.034567}

questions.question: Which numeric field shows the most spread in the dataset, and what are its quartiles and outlier bounds? Return as JSON with keys: column, q1, q3, iqr, lower_fence, upper_fence, n_outliers.
questions.hint: Find the numeric column with the highest variance, then compute its Q1, Q3, IQR and the lower/upper fences (1.5*IQR) to count outliers.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 7 keys: "column" (analyzed column), "q1" (25th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "q3" (75th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "iqr" (rounded to 4 decimals), "lower_fence" (rounded to 4 decimals), "upper_fence" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "n_outliers" (integer count). Example: {"column": "salary", "q1": 45000.0000, "q3": 75000.0000, "iqr": 30000.0000, "lower_fence": 0.0000, "upper_fence": 120000.0000, "n_outliers": 23}

questions.question: Which numeric attribute shows the greatest variability, and does its distribution appear normal? Return as JSON with keys: distribution, median, iqr.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the highest variance, conduct a Shapiro‑Wilk normality test (sampling if large), then report median and IQR if non‑normal.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 3 keys. If normal: {"distribution": "normal", "mean": <number>, "std": <number>}. If non-normal: {"distribution": "non-normal", "median": <number>, "iqr": <number>}. The "iqr" value is Q3 minus Q1 as a single number. All numeric values rounded to 3 decimal places.

questions.question: Which time period has the highest average member number? Return as JSON with keys: category_column, best_category, target_column, mean_value.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the greatest variance, then compute its mean for each categorical value and select the category with the highest mean.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "category_column" (the grouping column name), "best_category" (the category value with highest mean), "target_column" (the numeric column analyzed), and "mean_value" (rounded to 3 decimal places). Example: {"category_column": "region", "best_category": "West", "target_column": "sales", "mean_value": 1234.567}

questions.question: Are there any outliers in the numeric columns of this dataset, and how many columns contain them? Return as JSON with keys: columns_with_outliers, total_outliers.
questions.hint: For each numeric column compute mean and standard deviation, flag values farther than 3 × std from the mean, then count columns with at least one flag and sum all flagged values.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "columns_with_outliers" (integer count of columns containing at least one outlier) and "total_outliers" (integer total count of outlier values across all columns). Example: {"columns_with_outliers": 3, "total_outliers": 47}

questions.question: Are there any outliers in the numeric data, and how many columns contain them? Return as JSON with keys: columns_with_outliers, total_outliers.
questions.hint: Compute mean and standard deviation for each numeric column and count values that lie beyond 2.5 × std from the mean.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "columns_with_outliers" (integer count of columns containing at least one outlier) and "total_outliers" (integer total count of outlier values across all columns). Example: {"columns_with_outliers": 3, "total_outliers": 47}

questions.question: I wonder if any columns in the dataset have a substantial amount of missing data. Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Compute the missing percentage for each column and count those exceeding a 5% threshold.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}

questions.question: I wonder how many columns have a high proportion of missing values and which ones they are. Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Calculate the missing percentage for each column, compare to a threshold (e.g., 10%), and list columns exceeding it.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}

questions.question: Which numeric column in the data has the largest range, and what are its 10th, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 90th percentiles? Return as JSON with keys: column, p10, p25, p50, p75, p90.
questions.hint: Identify numeric columns, pick the one with the biggest max‑min difference, then compute the specified percentiles.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "column" (analyzed column), "p10" (10th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "p25" (25th percentile), "p50" (median), "p75" (75th percentile), and "p90" (90th percentile). Example: {"column": "income", "p10": 25000.0000, "p25": 40000.0000, "p50": 55000.0000, "p75": 75000.0000, "p90": 100000.0000}

questions.question: Which numeric column in this market basket data shows the greatest variability? Return as JSON with keys: column, count, mean, std, min, max, median, skewness, kurtosis.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the highest variance and then compute its descriptive statistics.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 9 keys: "column", "count" (integer), "mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), "std", "min", "max", "median", "skewness", and "kurtosis" (all rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "age", "count": 1000, "mean": 35.4567, "std": 12.3456, "min": 18.0000, "max": 85.0000, "median": 34.0000, "skewness": 0.5678, "kurtosis": -0.2345}
